content.user_title: Generate Game Test Cases in Minutes
content.value_statement: Game testing requires significant time to manually write comprehensive test cases from requirements. This skill uses AI to automatically generate professional test cases with normal, boundary, and exception scenarios, reducing test creation from 1 day to 10 minutes.
actual_capabilities: Parse requirement documents in xls, xlsx, csv, text, and image formats
Generate comprehensive test cases with normal, boundary, and exception scenarios
Produce two output formats: full test cases with steps and results, or quick test point checklists
Convert test case output to Excel or Xmind formats
Identify ambiguous requirements and recommend solutions
Organize test cases by game functional modules with priority classification
limitations: Cannot test actual game behavior or perform manual testing on devices
Quality depends on completeness of user-provided requirement documents
Requires AI model support for test case generation
Highly specialized game mechanics may need additional manual review

use_cases.title: QA Engineer Creates Test Documentation
use_cases.description: Upload a game requirement document and receive a complete test case suite organized by functional modules with scenarios covering normal flow, boundary values, and error conditions.

use_cases.title: Game Designer Reviews Requirements
use_cases.description: Use quick mode to generate test point lists for rapid requirement review meetings. Identify missing or ambiguous requirements before development begins.

use_cases.title: Project Manager Tracks Coverage
use_cases.description: Generate requirement-to-test-case mapping tables and coverage statistics to verify all requirements have corresponding test cases before development starts.

best_practices: Provide complete requirement documents with functional descriptions, UI specifications, and acceptance criteria for best results
Use full mode for formal test documentation and quick mode for review meetings and rapid iteration
Review and validate AI-generated test cases, especially for complex game mechanics
Export to Excel for test management systems or Xmind for visual review and team discussion
anti_patterns: Do not use the skill without providing any requirement document context
Do not expect the skill to actually run tests in a game environment
Do not skip manual review of generated test cases, especially for security-critical features
Do not rely solely on generated test cases for compliance or regulatory testing requirements

faq.question: What input formats does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill accepts xls, xlsx, csv files, plain text descriptions, and prototype images. For best results, include functional descriptions, UI specifications, and acceptance criteria.

faq.question: What is the difference between full mode and quick mode?
faq.answer: Full mode generates complete test cases with preconditions, numbered steps, expected results, and exception branches. Quick mode produces concise test point checklists suitable for review meetings.

faq.question: Can I customize the test case output format?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill outputs markdown by default. You can use the included Python scripts to convert to Excel (.xlsx) or Xmind-compatible markdown formats.

faq.question: How are test case priorities determined?
faq.answer: Priorities are assigned based on feature criticality: core gameplay and account security get high priority, common features get medium, and edge cases get low.

faq.question: Does the skill handle multi-module scenarios?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill identifies cross-module interactions and generates dedicated test cases for module-to-module scenarios such as login to character selection.

faq.question: Can I use this for non-game software testing?
faq.answer: The skill is optimized for game development with gaming-specific terminology and modules. It can be adapted for general software testing with manual adjustments.
